Fact: Once thought to be a dinosaur relative, it is now considered one of the closest known non‑pterosaur ancestors based on ankle and inner‑ear anatomy.
Once grouped with Pterodactylus, it shows early Jurassic pterosaur diversity.
Long considered a Pterodactylus, it had a distinctive tail vane.
Its reconstruction is heavily informed by the related Jeholopterus.
Juveniles resemble Ctenochasma, leading to many misassigned specimens.
It may belong to Anhanguerinae based on skull and tooth structure.
Both it and Nyctosaurus were discovered by Marsh and originally lumped into Pterodactylus.
It lived alongside Thalassodromeus and may connect evolutionarily to Tupandactylus.
A very small azhdarchoid, possibly the juvenile form of Sinopterus.
It lived at the very end of the dinosaurs’ reign.
Often mistaken for Pterodactylus or Noripterus due to similar skull features.
